sub_topic: Probability of a certain type of financial fraud occurring in a company
message_1: What is the probability that exactly 3 out of 10 randomly selected employees from a company's accounting department have committed financial fraud, given that the overall fraud rate in the department is 12%?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the binomial probability formula:

P(X = k) = C(n, k) * p^k * (1-p)^(n-k)

where:
- P(X = k) is the probability of exactly k successes (in this case, employees committing financial fraud) out of n trials (in this case, 10 randomly selected employees)
- C(n, k) is the number of combinations of n items taken k at a time, also written as n! / (k!(n-k)!)
- p is the probability of success (in this case, the fraud rate of 12% or 0.12)
- n is the number of trials (in this case, 10 employees)
- k is the number of successes (in this case, 3 employees committing fraud)

Plugging in the values:

P(X = 3) = C(10, 3) * 0.12^3 * (1-0.12)^(10-3)

First, calculate C(10, 3):

C(10, 3) = 10! / (3!(10-3)!) = 10! / (3!7!) = 120

Now, calculate the probability:

P(X = 3) = 120 * 0.12^3 * (1-0.12)^(10-3)
P(X = 3) = 120 * 0.12^3 * 0.88^7
P(X = 3) â‰ˆ 0.2302

So, the probability that exactly 3 out of 10 randomly selected employees from the accounting department have committed financial fraud is approximately 23.02%.
